title: Australian wine companies wrestle with shrinking UK
text:
"A lot of the supermarkets are a bit unsure as to whether they need to order more,'' Mr Taylor said.

"They seem to be as uncertain as they have ever been in the past.''

The UK market represents about 10 per cent of Taylors' total sales, and Mr Taylor said even a falling Australian dollar, which should make Australian wine more competitive on the shelves of UK retailers, was having a limited effect.

He said the company wasn't meeting its budgets in the UK and expected an extended downturn.

"We're extremely cautious there,'' he said.

Ordering patterns by customers were becoming more difficult to predict and some big retailers were privately fearful of a recession in the UK.

"The British consumer is extremely price sensitive,'' he said.

More broadly, the China market continues to be a bright spot for Australian wine exporters.

Wine Australia figures announced on Wednesday showed the value of total wine exports from Australia by the country's 2000 wine exporters climbed by 7 per cent to $2.89 billion.

Wine Australia chief executive Andreas Clark said there had been growth in all price segments above $5 per litre.

“The positive numbers also reflect that the average value of bottled wine to all but three of our top 20 destinations are in growth,'' he said.

Exports to Canada declined by 6 per cent to $188 million.

Australian wine exports to China, which included Hong Kong and Macau, hit a record value of $1.25 billion.

Mr Clark said while the UK economy remained soft because of uncertainty around Brexit, Australian wine labels on a combined basis still held the No.1 position in the retail market, which they had done for the past 20 years.
description: Taylors Wines boss Mitchell Taylor says UK supermarket customers are as uncertain as ever, and ordering patterns are volatile.
